question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Solve the inequality
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| < 5.\]
inference:
**Solution:**
$$|x-1|+|x+2|<5$$

**Case 1:** $x<-2$
$$-(x-1)-(x+2)<5$$ $$2x+3<5$$ $$2x<2$$ $$x<1$$

**Case 2:** $-2\leq x\leq 1$

$$x-1-(x+2)<5$$ $$-3<5$$ TRUE for all $x$ in this interval

**Case 3:** $x>1$
$$x-1+x+2<5$$ $$2x+1<5$$ $$2x<4$$ $$x<2$$

**Conclusion:**

The solution set is $$\boxed{x<-2 \quad \text{or} \quad -2\le x<2}$$

**Final Answer: $\boxed{x<-2 \quad \text{or} \quad -2\le x<2}$ I hope it is correct.**
ground_truth:
If $x < -2,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = -(x - 1) - (x + 2) = -2x - 1.\]Solving $-2x - 1 < 5,$ we get $x > -3.$  So, the values of $x$ that work in this case are $-3 < x < -2.$

If $-2 \le x < 1,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = -(x - 1) + (x + 2) = 3.\]All values in $-2 \le x < 1$ work.

If $1 \le x,$ then
\[|x - 1| + |x + 2| = (x - 1) + (x + 2) = 2x + 1.\]Solving $2x + 1 < 5,$ we get $x < 2.$  So the values of $x$ that work in this case are $1 \le x < 2.$

Therefore, the solution is $x \in \boxed{(-3,2)}.$
